title: Clickjacking Vulnerability on https://support.my.com/games/ticket/xxxx/
vulnerability_information:
Hi There,

I have found a Clickjacking vulnerability on your site.

Steps to reproduce:
1.Go to https://support.my.com this site
2.Generate a Clickjacking script, save it as .html and run into your browser
Script:
<html>
<--Report Generated by Clickjacking Test v1.0--> 
<style>
iframe { 
width: 800px; 
height: 500px; 
position: absolute; 
top: 0; left: 0; 
filter: alpha(opacity=50); 
opacity: 0.5; 
} 
</style>
<iframe src="https://support.my.com/games/ticket/3142879/">
</html>

## Impact

Clickjacking on support ticket

The hacker selected the **UI Redressing (Clickjacking)** weakness. This vulnerability type requires contextual information from the hacker. They provided the following answers:

**URL**
https://support.my.com/games/ticket/xxxxxxxxx/

**Can a victim be tricked into unknowingly initiating a specific action?**
Yes

**What specific action can the user be tricked into?**
Ticket

activities.message:
Thank you for your report to Mail.Ru Group!   We appreciate your time for helping us to make our web services safer.

(Un)fortunately, we can't confirm your report as a real security threat. If you still think you have found a real security vulnerability, you can try to find an exploitation scenario with security impact.
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your report to Mail.Ru Group! We appreciate your time for helping us to make our web services safer.

(Un)fortunately, we can't confirm your report as a real security threat. If you still think you have found a real security vulnerability, you can try to find an exploitation scenario with security impact.

Hi @3apa3a,
An attacker can perform any authorize action on behalf of the user using drag and drop tricks.

Impact:

An attacker can close/comment/edit the support ticket.
Example of clickjacking script:
<html>
<head>
<title>Clickjack test page</title>
<style>
iframe {
width: 900px;
height: 800px;
/* Use absolute positioning to line up update button with fake button /
position: absolute;
top: 100px;
left: 100px;
z-index: 2;
/ Hide from view */
-moz-opacity: 0.2;
opacity: 0.2;
filter: alpha(opacity=0.2);
}
button {
position: absolute;
top: 330px;
left: 100px;
z-index: 1;
width: 65px;
}
</style>
</head
<body>
<p>website is VULNERABLE to click jacking!</p>
<iframe src="https://support.my.com/games/ticket/3142879" height="700" width="1000"></iframe>
</body>

For Fix:
it is missing a X-FRAME header. a user with the help of some tricky css can trick user click on the one click actions. . You should apply a X-FRAME header

Similiar report:
https://hackerone.com/reports/8724
https://hackerone.com/reports/355774

Best
Yeasir Arafat

@3apa3a,
I explained the security impact here. Let me know if you have any questions.
Thanks

activities.message:
Hi @3apa3a, 
I have found valid clickjacking vulnerability on two more your sites. If you want I can send you new reports. 
Kindly respond. 
Thanks

summaries.content:
Reporter filed a report of clickjacking vulnerability without identifying any real exploitation scenario. According to Mail.Ru bug bounty program's rules, clickjacking reports without practical impact are not accepted.

There is seems no practical security impact from this report, because exploitation requires attacker to know which ticket belongs to user and content of the ticket, and even with this information exploitation may require multiple unlikely actions from user. These facts were not validated by reporter, a result of automated scan was reported instead,

In general, page framing/clickjacking should never be reported as a vulnerability. Clickjacking is an exploitation vector rather than vulnerability and ability to frame the page is not vulnerability by itself. Never report clickjacking scan results without identifying clickjacking as an attack vector in any real exploitation scenario with real security impact.

An example of *invalid* clickjacking report is:
"UI redressing due to missed X-Frame-Options"
(clickjacking reported as a vulnerability)

An examples of *valid* clickjacking report are:
"An ability to confirm OAuth trust via clickjacking"
"An ability to remove user's account via clickjacking"
"An ability to modify user's profile data via clickjacking"
(clickjacking reported as an attack vector)

These facts were not validated by reporter, a result of automated scan was reported instead,

In general, page framing/clickjacking should never be reported as a vulnerability. Clickjacking is an exploitation vector rather than vulnerability and ability to frame the page is not vulnerability by itself. Never report clickjacking scan results without identifying clickjacking as an attack vector in any real exploitation scenario with real security impact.

An example of invalid clickjacking report is:

An examples of valid clickjacking report are:
